H0.text: A base is what acidic hydrogen atoms will be transferred to.

H1.text: Water is the acceptor of acidic hydrogen atoms.

H2.text: A cup is the substance to which acidic hydrogen atoms are transferred.

H3.text: Another atom is the recipient to which acidic hydrogen atoms are transferred.

A4.text: A base is a substance that can accept hydrogen cations (H+).

A5.text: G. N. Lewis realized that water, ammonia, and other bases can form a bond with a proton due to the unshared pair of electrons that the bases possess.

A6.text: A Brønsted–Lowry acid (or simply Brønsted acid) is a species that donates a proton to a Brønsted–Lowry base.

A7.text: An Arrhenius acid is a substance that increases the concentration of hydronium ions when added to water.

A8.text: Water is amphoteric as it can act as an acid or as a base.

A9.text: Ammonium salts behave as acids, and metal amides behave as bases.
